Award.AwardTitle: Targeted Infusion Project: Integration of Renewable - Solar & Wind Energy into the Engineering Curriculum

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project in the College of Engineering, Technology & Physical Sciences at Alabama A&M University (AAMU) will enhance the engineering and technology curriculum by integrating theoretical and hands-on experiences in the field of renewable energy. This will be achieved by introducing new undergraduate and graduate courses in solar, wind and other renewable energies; introducing hands-on laboratory experience in solar and wind energy; enhancing the quality of education by introducing and expanding undergraduate and graduate research opportunities; and strengthening the recruitment, retention and transition of engineering and science students from secondary to post-graduate studies and industry.

Project activities will advance the knowledge of the student participants, sharpen their skills and provide a support system that empowers them to successfully graduate and succeed in a competitive job market. By integrating theory, lab experiences and research into multidisciplinary renewable energy courses, students will be engaged in the learning process. The project will impact more than two hundred students at AAMU, as well as about four hundred high school students. Project activities can serve as a model for other institutions that desire to strengthen their engineering and technology programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The College of Engineering, Technology & Physical Sciences (CETPS) at Alabama A&M University (AAMU) is committed to enhance the engineering, technology and science curriculum based on current market demand to elevate the quality of the graduates. AAMU is a Historically Black University (HBCU) providing high quality education for a culturally diverse student population of which 91% are African-American students. Renewable Energy is an alternate source of clean energy which is abundantly available in nature, will save the environment by reducing pollution, and also alleviate the foreign dependency on fossil fuel. It is an emerging field in which many government agencies and private organizations are heavily investing in research and implementation. As a result, there will be huge demand for engineers and technologists with experience in renewable energy. CETPS at AAMU received this grant from NSF for the period July 2013 – June 2016, and plans to address the national energy crisis by producing a quality pool of underrepresented engineers and scientists with experience in renewable energy and develop a diverse national workforce through achieving the following four goals: 1) Enhance Engineering and Science Curriculum by introducing new undergraduate and graduate courses in solar, wind and other renewable energies; 2) Introduce hands-on experience in solar and wind energy; 3) Enhance the quality of education by introducing and expanding undergraduate and graduate research opportunities; 4) Increase the recruitment, retention and transition of engineering and science students from secondary to post-graduate studies and industry.

The project intends to enhance the engineering and technology curriculum at AAMU by integrating theoretical and hands-on experience in the cutting edge field of renewable energy. Hence, two new undergraduate and graduate level courses have been developed during the 2013-2014 academic year for the mechanical, electrical & civil engineering and science students: ME441/ME541 Renewable Energy (3 credit hours), and ME442/ME542 Solar Thermal Engineering (3 credit hours). The newly developed courses have been added to the curricula and being offered since Fall 2014. New Computer Controlled Photovoltaic Solar Energy Unit and Computer Controlled Wind Energy Unit have been purchased with this NSF Project grant from Edibon-USA and installed in the Mechanical Engineering laboratory. New labs on Solar and Wind Energy related to the above course curricula have been developed.

ME441/ME541 Renewable Energy has been offered during Fall 2014 and Fall 2015 semesters, and ME442/ME542 Solar Thermal Engineering has again been offered during Spring 2015 and Spring 2016 semesters. On an average 15 students took these courses each semester, the students were very enthusiastic and their performance was quite satisfactory.

A cohort of seven talented engineering and technology students were selected in 2014-2015, and a cohort of six students were selected in 2015-2016 academic years to participate in research with faculty mentors (PI and Co-PIs). The PI and Co-PIs did an excellent job in mentoring and guiding their research work in renewable energy. Each student also received a stipend. As a result, there were total six Poster Presentations made by these students on renewable energy during the STEM Day 2015 and STEM Day 2016 Conferences held at Alabama A&M University. Abstracts of the presentations were published in the conference proceedings. One of these groups received the “First Prize” for their poster presentation, which was also published in the College Newsletter.

Out of these 13 students doing research in renewable energy, 5 students have graduated and remaining 8 are continuing their studies. This means the retention rate for this cohort is 100% which is significantly high compared to the college average retention rate.  Also, all the 5 students graduated with research experience in renewable energy were employed or enrolled into graduate school.

By providing students opportunity to graduate from programs in cutting edge fields and having higher demands in job market, will encourage them to focus on learning and to graduate on time, which in turn will increase enrollment, retention and graduation rate of underrepresented minorities and improve diversity in national workforce, as supported by the above data.

Information about the success of these new Renewable Energy courses and research at Alabama A&M University was published in the local newspaper “Huntsville Times”, AAMU online newsletter “Bulldog BottomLine”, and CETPS Newsletter. The PI was Invited to talk about Renewable Energy at the American Association of University Women (AAUW) Meeting, published in the AAUW online Newsletter. The PI also made a presentation about the success of their Renewable Energy project at the NSF HBCU-UP PI/PD Meeting at Washington DC in February 2016. This helps to disseminate the knowledge obtained from this project, so that these successful activities can be replicated by all HBCU/MIs and other similar sized institutions that desire to improve engineering and technology education.
